template.p: This powerful inventory application enables complete control over your product catalog and stock management, ensuring your inventory data is always accurate.
Start by creating your products within the Products tab, filling in all necessary details. The system uses three distinct categories to provide maximum flexibility across your business:

li.p: Product Category: For internal tracking and reporting.
E-commerce Category: For easier product retrieval by customers on your online store.
Point of Sale Category: For organizing transactions within your shop system.
Accurately update the inventoried quantity.
Decide whether to allow sales of out-of-stock products.
Define product variants for an improved e-commerce customer journey. Important: Only assign a single value per attribute to prevent the system from creating separate stock entities.

o_editor_banner_content o-contenteditable-true w-100 px-3
div.p: If you need lot and expiry date tracking for your products, first enable those features in Inventory Settings, and then apply the specific tracking type to the products themselves.

template.p: Once products are created, you must establish how and when they should be restocked. There are two primary methods:
Set minimal and maximal stock levels for a product. Based on your trigger setting (Automated or Manual):

li.p: Automated Trigger will instantly create a purchase order.
Manual Trigger will display the demand in the Inventory Replenishment view for you to confirm. (Note: Reordering rules work in conjunction with defined lead times.)

template.p: When working within a new purchase order, look for the Suggest toggle on the catalog (available from the purchase line).
Activating this feature allows the app to propose a replenishment quantity calculated over a set number of days. You can also apply a percentage factor if you anticipate a change in demand.
Optimal stock management is achieved by combining both the Reordering Rules and Suggested Replenishment to ensure a comprehensive, forecast-aware stock follow-up.

div.p: These tools allow you to manage your sales strategy and customer interactions effectively:

li.p: Pricelist Segmentation: Define multiple pricing structures for the same product, supporting different business models (e.g., B2B vs. B2C) and enabling client-specific pricing contracts.
Promotional Agility: Use discounts and promotions to quickly adjust pricing for sales events or to give targeted, manual reductions at the point of sale.
Loyalty Programs: Implement loyalty cards as a core strategy to activate customer retention and increase lifetime value.

template.p: Your e-commerce setup involves three main areas: Product Settings, Website-Wide Settings, and Payment & Delivery Methods.

li.p: Publishing: Each product can be published independently on your online store.
Product-Level Settings: Define core product settings directly on the product form.
Layout Settings: Adjust the visual presentation and layout of products using the website editor.
Navigate to Website Settings to configure global e-commerce policies.

Crucial Review: You must review all e-commerce settings to ensure they align with your internal business policies (e.g., when invoices are generated, whether a mandatory customer check-in is required for ordering, etc.).

template.p: Use the Website > Configuration menu to enable all your transaction options.

li.p: Payment Providers & Methods: Go to Website > Configuration > Payment Providers and install all the payment methods and providers you plan to offer (e.g., credit card processors, PayPal, etc.).
Delivery Methods: Go to Website > Configuration > Delivery Methods to define all available options and their costs.
External Providers: Check if a predefined Odoo connection exists if you work with specific shipping carriers.
In-Store Pickup (Click & Collect): If you wish to offer this, you must activate the setting within the Website Settings first.

template.p: When an e-commerce order is placed:

li.p: It automatically creates a Sales Order in your Sales App.
This Sales Order generates a linked Delivery Order.
The Delivery Order instantly reserves the ordered product in your inventory.

If a product reserved for an online order is later sold physically in your store, the system will identify the resulting stock shortage, and the need for that product will appear in the Replenishment view (as detailed in the inventory settings).

div.p: To prevent selling products already promised to online customers, immediately move incoming e-commerce orders to a separate storage location. Since your Point of Sale (POS) system won't show an alert for stock reserved by a delivery order, physically segregating the items is essential to guarantee fulfillment.

template.p: Use these settings to tailor the experience for your B2B clients:

li.p: Define B2B Pricing: Create and assign a dedicated pricelist to each B2B contact. Ensure this pricelist is active on your website so the customer sees their agreed-upon prices upon login.
Capture Requests: Any submission via the "Contact Us" page instantly generates a new CRM opportunity.
Qualify Leads: Engage with the client through the CRM opportunity to fully understand their request‚Äîwhether it's a need for a specific product, a supplier inquiry, or general information.
Quote and Confirm: If a specific demand requires pricing, generate a quotation directly from the opportunity. The client can then confirm and sign it online.
Automatic Delivery: Once the quote is accepted, the system automatically creates a linked Delivery Order, just as it does for a regular e-commerce order.
